items.content_html:
Summary

To add the documentation for the new Scripting API, including:

  • scripting (pending)
  • scripting.executeScript (pending)
  • scripting.insertCSS (draft included)
  • scripting.removeCSS (draft included)
  • scripting.getRegisteredContentScripts (pending)
  • scripting.registerContentScripts (pending)
  • scripting.unregisterContentScripts (pending)
  • scripting.updateContentScripts (pending)
  • release note (pending)
  • Updates to tabs, tabs.insertCSS(), tabs.removeCSS(), and tabs.executeScript() (pending)
  • scripting permission to permissions and optional permissions (pending)

Related issues

Addresses the requirements of these Bugzilla tickets:

  • 1736579 Implement scripting.insertCSS()
  • 1736580 Implement scripting.removeCSS()
  • 1736581 Implement scripting.getRegisteredContentScripts()
  • 1736582 Initial implementation of scripting.registerContentScripts()
  • 1736584 Implement scripting.unregisterContentScripts()
  • 1736585 Implement scripting.updateContentScripts()

items.title: ARIA Landing page: updated content

items.content_html:
This adds a workflow to automatically lock issues and PRs that have been closed for more than a year.

This should reduce the instance of "necrobumping" - adding follow-on discussions to issues that are long closed and often not relevant. Even if used in "good faith", this is not a good idea because the old issue was addressed, and the detail on a year old issue is likely to be out of date or incorrect.

The implementation is directly copied from https://github.com/dessant/lock-threads#examples and uses all defaults:

  • Locks issues after 365 days of a PR or issue being inactive.

NOTE: I personally think this is a good idea, and there was some support on slack. I have not yet "tested" this.
items.title: Workflow to auto-lock old closed issues and PRs

items.content_html:
Fixes #14558

Generally Ubuntu/Linux users have a tantrum when you suggest using sudo to resolve permission errors. However this is "Learn" content, and if we want users to be able to follow it then we can't expect Linux expertise. From my research using sudo with NPM is actually recommended, in particular if you use the H or i flags to make sure that the files are installed to correct locations for current user.

Upshot, I think this is OK with a caveat "there are monsters here".
I have highlighted the specific relevant changes with inline comments.
items.title: NPM installation on Ubuntu requires sudo

items.content_html:
This PR is part of openwebdocs/project#92.

The idea here is to simplify the page:

  • Reorganize the different syntaxes in one block as we do elsewhere on MDN. In one glance, all the possible syntaxes are visible.
  • Put the modern, space-separated, syntax first.
  • Get rid of mentions of CSS Color Level4: the developer only needs to know if this is supported or not
  • Get rid of the note saying that hsla() is an alias. I put this in the See also section, this will stay prominent in hsla() as we want to lower its use, but not here.
  • Describe each parameter separately.

Note that the spec and browser compat sections, although defined correctly, are only partially displayed until mdn/browser-compat-data#15646 is resolved. (This is also the cause of the flaw reported by our Preview URLs bot)

This is the first color function to be reorganized. The idea is to do the same for each of the 7 others.
items.title: Reorganize the hsl() page

items.content_html:
Part of openwebdocs/project#92 (revamp our color guide and reference).

This PR moves the system-related color keywords into their own page (taking them off the <color> page).

Note:

  • There is much more work to be done on the <color> page, I intentionally limited this PR by moving the color keywords only.
  • We don't have BCD info for these, so I didn't add a Browser compatibility section to it (I'll see if I have time to come back to this during this project, but this is secondary).
items.title: Move CSS system color keywords to their own page

items.content_html:
"targetWindow" variable was missing from primary example. This may cause confusion.

Summary

Include targetWindow variable in primary example. This is part of the syntax and is mentioned in the proceeding syntax explanation, though the fact that the variable is missing may cause confusion to unfamiliar developers.

Motivation

To help improve the clarity and effectiveness of the documentation.

Supporting details

Further examples show "targetWindow" - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/postMessage#example

Related issues

items.content_html:
Summary

min and max can be both a string or a number... right? I don't know how I would represent an iso8601 date as a number. In fact, the examples show all of these are strings except number and range

Motivation

fix an (assumed) error

Supporting details

From MDN:

Input type Example Example
date yyyy-mm-dd <input type="date" min="2019-12-25" step="1">
month yyyy-mm <input type="month" min="2019-12" step="12">
week yyyy-W## <input type="week" min="2019-W23" step="">
time hh:mm <input type="time" min="09:00" step="900">
datetime-local yyyy-mm-ddThh:mm <input type="datetime-local" min="2019-12-25T19:30">
number <number> <input type="number" min="0" step="5" max="100">
range <number> <input type="range" min="60" step="5" max="100">

Related issues

n/a

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error

similar PR: #14481
items.title: Clarify that min can also be a string
